abstract.para: The topic covers switching of modes using the setenforce command and by changing the permanent configuration.

topic.para: You can switch the &selnx; mode temporarily or permanently.

section.title: Changing the &selnx; mode temporarily
section.para: To set &selnx; to the permissive or enforcing temporarily, use the command setenforce.

Remember that you cannot disable &selnx; using the setenforce command.

section.title: Changing the &selnx; mode permanently
section.para: To perform changes to the &selnx; mode that persists rebooting of the system, edit the /etc/selinux/config configuration file. In this file, you can also disable &selnx; on your system. However, this action is not recommended. If &selnx; is possibly causing issues to your system, switch to the permissive mode instead and debug your system.

The changes in the file are applied after the next reboot.

note.title: Relabeling your system after switching from the disabled mode
note.para: If you disable &selnx; on your system and then enable it later, make sure that you relabel your system. When &selnx; is disabled and you perform changes to your file system, the changes are not reflected in the context anymore (for example, new files do not have any context). Therefore, you need to relabel your system by using the restorecon command, using the autorelabel boot parameter, or by creating a file that will trigger relabeling on the next boot.
